Authors:
Charuwan Chuaseeharonnachai, Sayanh Somrithipol, Satinee
Suetrong, Anupong Klaysuban, Nattawut Boonyuen, Natapol Pornputtapong,
E.B. Gareth Jones
Title:
Conioscypha nakagirii sp. nov., from naturally submerged wood
in Thailand based on nuclear ribosomal and protein-coding genes
Keywords:
asexual morph, fungal systematics, LSU and SSU rDNA,
morphology, phylogeny, RPB2, submerged substrata
Abstract:
Conioscypha nakagirii, a novel fungus, was identified,
illustrated and described from decaying submerged wood collected in a
small stream in Pak Chong District, Nakhon Ratchasima Province,
Thailand. Morphologically, it differs from known Conioscypha species and
similar taxa in that it has large, turbinate to pyriform, black and
smooth-walled conidia. Phylogenetic analyses of the combined partial
nuclear small and large subunits ribosomal DNA (nuc 18S and nuc 28S) and
the second largest subunit of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase II largest
subunit (RPB2) indicate that this taxon is a member of order
Conioschyphales, Subclass Hypocreomycetidae, Class Sordariomycetes, in a
well-supported clade. It formed a sister group to Conioscypha lignicola,
C. japonica, C. varia and C. peruviana, and shares some morphological
characteristics with C. fabiformis and C. taiwaniana. Both morphological
and molecular evidence justify the introduction of the new species, C.
nakagirii, and a key to Conioscypha species is also provided.
